verses.text: O LORD, God of vengeance, God of vengeance, shine forth!
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes the justice of God in a world marred by evil. Early Christianity recognized God's vengeance as righteous and perfect, foreshadowing the final judgment (see 2 Thessalonians 1:6).

verses.text: Rise up, O Judge of the earth; repay the proud what they deserve.
verses.comment: God as judge foreshadows Christ as the one appointed to judge both living and dead (Acts 10:42), connecting this Psalm to Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: How long, O LORD, shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked exult?
verses.comment: "How long?" echoes the cry for deliverance found throughout Psalms. This longing is fulfilled in Christ, who conquers the wicked (Revelation 6:10).

verses.text: They pour out arrogant words; all evildoers boast.
verses.comment: The pride of evildoers is a recurring theme opposed to humility, a virtue emphasized in Christ and exemplified by the saints.

verses.text: They crush your people, O LORD, and afflict your heritage.
verses.comment: The term 'heritage' refers to Israel, God's chosen people, but in the Christian understanding, extends to all who enter the covenant—beautifully fulfilled in the Church, called the new Israel (Galatians 6:16).

verses.text: They kill the widow and the sojourner, and murder the fatherless.
verses.comment: God's heart for the defenseless reflects His compassion, fully revealed in Christ’s ministry and the Church’s works of mercy.

verses.text: And they say, 'The LORD does not see; the God of Jacob does not understand.'
verses.comment: Denial of God’s providence leads to moral disaster; God's knowledge and omnipresence are central to orthodox faith, echoing wisdom literature and Christ’s teaching (Matthew 10:30).

verses.text: Understand, you dullest of the people! Fools, when will you become wise?
verses.comment: Wisdom is a gift from God and flourishes with openness to His revelation, mirrored in the Church’s call to conversion and deeper understanding.

verses.text: He who planted the ear, does he not hear? He who formed the eye, does he not see?
verses.comment: The Psalmist rebukes materialism and atheism; God’s intimate knowledge of every creature, reaffirmed by Christ (Matthew 6:26), points to divine providence.

verses.text: He who disciplines the nations, does he not rebuke? He who teaches mankind knowledge?
verses.comment: God’s discipline is formative, as in Hebrews 12:6; the Church views divine correction as a path to holiness.

verses.text: The LORD knows the thoughts of man, that they are but a breath.
verses.comment: 'A breath' evokes human frailty; a persistent call in Catholic spirituality to trust God rather than self (James 4:14).

verses.text: Blessed is the man whom you discipline, O LORD, and whom you teach from your law,
verses.comment: Blessedness through discipline parallels Christ’s teaching on true happiness in the Beatitudes; ‘law’ here is Torah, but Catholics also see it fulfilled in the law of Christ (see Sermon on the Mount, Matthew 5-7).

verses.text: to give him rest from days of trouble, until a pit is dug for the wicked.
verses.comment: God preserves His faithful; ultimate rest is found in Christ, who offers peace and salvation. The Church teaches ‘rest’ as a foretaste of eternal life.

verses.text: For the LORD will not forsake his people; he will not abandon his heritage.
verses.comment: Divine faithfulness is a theme echoed by Paul (Romans 11:1). The Church interprets ‘heritage’ as the communion of saints, continued from Israel to the universal Church.

verses.text: For judgment will return to righteousness, and all the upright in heart will follow it.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is restorative, pointing toward the final judgment and reward for the righteous; parallels the Catholic vision of the Beatific Vision.

verses.text: Who will rise up for me against the wicked? Who will stand up for me against evildoers?
verses.comment: This rallying cry invites us to join God’s cause. The authentic Christian (and Catholic) vocation is to stand for truth and justice in communion with Christ and his Body, the Church.

verses.text: If the LORD had not helped me, my soul would soon have dwelt in the land of silence.
verses.comment: ‘Land of silence’ refers to Sheol, the realm of the dead. The Church sees this as an anticipation of Christ’s victory over death (1 Corinthians 15:54).

verses.text: When I said, 'My foot slips,' your steadfast love, O LORD, held me up.
verses.comment: Steadfast love (Heb. ‘hesed’) is God’s covenant faithfulness. In Catholic teaching, grace is the stabilizing force, especially given in the sacraments.

verses.text: When the cares of my heart are many, your consolations cheer my soul.
verses.comment: God’s comfort is a recurring grace, reminiscent of the Holy Spirit’s role as Para­clete (John 14:26). Catholic spirituality often emphasizes interior consolation.

verses.text: Can wicked rulers be allied with you, those who frame injustice by statute?
verses.comment: Unjust rulers are condemned, anticipating the necessity of righteous governance—seen in the Church’s commitment to social justice and doctrine on authority.

verses.text: They band together against the righteous and condemn the innocent to death.
verses.comment: The plot against the innocent prefigures Christ, the Innocent condemned to death. Catholics see this fulfilled in Jesus's Passion.

verses.text: But the LORD has become my stronghold, and my God the rock of my refuge.
verses.comment: ‘Rock’ alludes to God’s stability. Catholic tradition, echoing Matt. 16:18, sees a typological connection to Peter and the Church as the refuge and rock.

verses.text: He will bring back on them their iniquity and will destroy them in their wickedness; the LORD our God will wipe them out.
verses.comment: God’s retributive justice is shown here. Ultimate destruction of the wicked points to final judgment and the triumph of divine justice, a theme foundational in Church teaching on eschatology.
